Write an email in my voice.
To: 'Les Johnson' <[REDACTED_EMAIL]>, Robert Hampson <[REDACTED_EMAIL]>
Subject: Space Stations

Hi Les, Rob,

I think, with this new administration, we should propose a bold space 
exploration initiative -- a new High Frontier.¬† I think our nation works 
best when challenged, the bigger the challenge, the better.

Listening to NASA experts on the biological effects of microgravity, it 
becomes clear that man cannot survive and thrive in a "zero-gee" 
environment. So that means we have to have gravity (how much is not 
clear, some say lunar gravity would do the trick).

I think, in terms of bold exploration we should move from the baby step 
of exploring space to the more profound concept of living in space -- 
that we should build rotating space stations which provide all the way 
up to 1.0 gravities.

Further that we should target the goal of completely self-sustaining 
space stations. We're going to need to know how to build completely 
self-sustaining habitats if we want to exploit the solar system.¬† And 
we're going to need to know how to build completely self-sustaining 
habitats if we're going to travel to the stars.

I read and well remember NASA SP-428: Space Resources and Space 
Settlements, as well as "Space Settlements: A Design Study," so I recall 
the state of the art in the 1970s.

We have over 20 years of understanding life in zero gravity, and we know 
how *assemble* a space station in orbit. What we don't know is how to 
build a rotating space station nor how much the coriolis effect will 
affect humans.

Building a self-sustaining rotating space station will also allow us to 
fully understand a closed-loop environment -- what we learn from that 
will be directly applicable to our issues with global warming and 
climate change (aside from offering a bolthole).

Building a self-sustaining rotating space station is the first step 
toward building habitats throughout the stars.¬† I would expect that we 
would plan on building more than one station, each one improving on the 
design of the former.¬† It should be possible to profitably move certain 
industries up to the stations (part of their self-sufficiency).

I wonder how hard it would be to pitch it to the President, 
Vice-President and Congress.

What do you guys think?

-- Todd

On Wed, Jun 16, 2021 at 8:42 PM todd <[REDACTED_EMAIL] 
<mailto:[REDACTED_EMAIL]>> wrote:

 Dear Mr Lee,

 I would like to request someone to fix the A/C. Here is the situation.
 The A/C system is one condenser with two internal thermostats, one
 upstairs and one down stairs. There is a damper, which is movable flap
 inside the duct work that directs air flow downstair or upstairs
 depending on the settings of the thermostat.

 At some point in time in the past one of the thermostats was
 disconnected and so the damper does not adjust airflow, since there is
 only one thermostat attached.

 I would like to get the second thermostat reconnected and confirm the
 damper is working correctly to cool both floors as soon as possible.

 As it is right now, the AC is running continuously. Even when the
 system
 is turned OFF, the fans still run. When the system is set to COOL, the
 thermostat setting downstairs has no effect -- and the system runs
 continuously, without regards to temperature (the temperature has been
 68 when the thermostat was set to 72), nothing short of turning the AC
 to OFF on the thermostat effects that (and, as I said, even then the
 fans continue to run). None of this can be good for the AC system.

 At this very moment, my room temperature is 79.3 degrees which is
 intolerable.

 I look forward to hearing from you immediately.

 Sincerely,
 Todd McCaffrey

Hi Todd,

At first sight, science fiction and romance seem to be genres that are 
not compatible. For the most part they are, if you examine the 
demographics of the majority of readers in the two categories.

But that does not prevent individual writers from bringing the two 
genres together and doing incredibly well with it.

Sci-Fi Romance was one of the first niche market reports based on our 
"Virtual Besteller List" approach that we published back in 2016. In the 
meantime, the category has grown into a significant market.

Traditional publishers have left money on the table while indie authors 
have conquered the space (both figuratively and literally).

Both sci-fi and romance provide escapism to readers during these 
challenging times. So if you can imagine writing a story about 
intergalactic love, warring species, hunky alien heroes ‚Äî blue, purple, 
and fiercely protective or possessive of their women ‚Äî then look no further.

You‚Äôve hit the **infamous Windows line endings problem** (the `^M`/`\r` issue)!

### **Why?**
When a script is created/edited in Windows (including many editors, or when files are checked out with `core.autocrlf`), it uses **CRLF** (`\r\n`) line endings, but Unix/Linux (including WSL) expects just **LF** (`\n`). 
Bash chokes on the `\r` at the end of each line.

---

## **How to Fix: Convert the Script to Unix Line Endings**

### **Option 1: With `dos2unix` (Recommended if installed)**
```bash
dos2unix run_dev.sh
```
Then try again:
```bash
./run_dev.sh
```

### **Option 2: With `sed` (no new tools needed)**
```bash
sed -i 's/\r$//' run_dev.sh
```
Then run as usual.

### **Option 3: In VS Code or Sublime Text**
- Open the file.
- In the lower right, click ‚ÄúCRLF‚Äù and change to ‚ÄúLF.‚Äù
- Save.

---

## **Extra: Making Scripts Executable and Runnable**

- Make sure it‚Äôs executable:
 ```bash
 chmod +x run_dev.sh
 ```
- Then run:
 ```bash
 ./run_dev.sh
 ```

---

## **Summary Checklist**
- Convert line endings to Unix (`LF`)
- Make script executable
- Run with `./run_dev.sh` (not `sh run_dev.sh`)

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Problem:
The default `nginx:alpine` image includes a **default `index.html`**, so **your `ll.html` might not be served as the default page**, and Nginx could be serving its built-in one (or nothing at all if it‚Äôs removed incorrectly).

Summarize this excerpt from 'JG' in 3‚Äì5 sentences. Keep names and key stakes.

Excerpt:
Lights will be on late at the Kremlin tonight. # Deep Space Network, Goldstone, Arizona "My god!" John Ahrens, radio technician at Goldstone exclaimed as Zhukov's voice faded into silence. "Roger, Harmonie, we copy." Chris Rogers, the unflappable station chief, responded to the stale message. "We will initiate a DSN emergency at this time. All receivers are being alerted. Good luck, Goldstone out." Rogers pulled off his headset and turned to stare at Ahrens for a long moment. "Mr. Ahrens, in future, please keep your comments to yourself." Reprimand delivered, he continued in the same tones: "Gentleman, please ensure that all DSN stations are alerted to this emergency." He looked at Ivan Petrovich. "Mr. Petrovich, a complete downlink has been sent to den Haag, do you need anything else?" Ivan Petrovich nodded his head. "I shall need a phone presently." The beady-eyed, wiry Russian made an attempt at a smile. "And if you have any good luck charms or prayers, I think they're in order." Ahrens guffawed but Rogers merely blinked. "Yes, of course." He gestured. "You can use the phone in my office." As soon as the door was closed, Rogers turned to the radio console. Ahrens looked on in surprise as Rogers spun the dials. "Whitestar, Whitestar this is Goldbird." Rogers' words rattled out. "Prepare for flash traffic " He paused, turned to survey a computer console, keyed in a quick sequence and finished. " now!" Two lights blinked on the computer console. A look of satisfaction crossed Rogers' face. "Goldbird out." With unnatural speed, Rogers spun the radio dials and returned the station to its original frequency. He fixed a long, hard look on Ahrens. "You saw nothing," Rogers told him in a whispered version of his usual slow bass rattle. The office door opened before Ahrens could respond and the Russian emerged, looking relieved. "Everything all right?" Ahrens asked. "I have informed Eurocos." Petrovich responded. "They are rather " he paused significantly " excited." # The White House, Washington, D.C. The Vice President was dumb. There was no question about it.

As fleet shuttles went, it was mid-sized, capable of hauling several hundred personnel or a month's worth of supplies for a frigate or corvette. Two of them would supply a destroyer; four, a cruiser ‚Äì the largest ship in His Majesty's Navy. Aside from the pilot, co-pilot, and flight engineer, the ship was filled with those returning from leave or going to their first assignments. Officers, enlisted, and warrant officers were all in the mix. Ophelia was seated next to Nick Dean, another Academy graduate who was moaning about his assignment to Fearless. "She's the oldest cruiser in the Navy and her captain's almost older," Nick grumbled by way of bragging. Captain Adrian Wardlaw was nearly two hundred years old, had seen combat with the old Pevencee pirates, and was famous for his refusal to accept higher rank or retirement. As he'd been personal friends with the first King and known the current King when he was only in diapers, there was no one who would tell him otherwise. His ship was also the command ship for the Home Fleet which put him at the beck and call of Admiral Omicron Katzelos ‚Äì though it was rumored that it was mostly the other way around. Ophelia recalled only that her mother never said anything about the Home Fleet's admiral, and that all she'd heard in the Academy was that the admiral was "a great administrator." Write one paragraph describing the tone, mood, and narrative voice of this excerpt from 'JG'.

Excerpt:
Zhukov spared time only to shout hoarsely: "Stations!" before he ducked out of the mess, climbing to the Angle where he jumped from the rotating Crew Section to the zero-gee Command Section. With a yell of "Make way!", he kicked off and floated out in zero-gee to the bridge. The Bridge was divided into four parts representing the key sections of operation of Harmonie: Communications, Navigation, Life Support, and Propulsion. Everything was automated; typically there was only the officer of the deck and a crewman to oversee all control of Harmonie. Gregor Ivanovich Strasnoye was the officer on duty. He was one of the few Russian officers on Harmonie hand-picked by Zhukov as an up-and-coming young officer. It did not hinder, Nikolai reflected, that Gregor's father was . Gregor was in the Nav quadrant. On the main screen was an overhead display of their trajectory around Jupiter. Blinking a baleful red was an object some distance from Harmonie's current position but its course, marked in dotted lines, indicated a collision hazard. By now the other officers had made their way to their stations. Elodie and Karl took stations just behind each of his shoulders, making Nikolai distinctly nervous. Nikolai turned around, gave his two first officers a slight grin, and shouted across to Propulsion: "Murray, stand by for evasive action." "Righto, Skipper!" Zhukov turned back to Gregor: "How much will we need?" "Not much, sir, it's just that " "Don't babble, man, do the burn!" Nikolai interrupted. Gregor licked his lips nervously, started to say something, thought better of it and turned back to the main Nav console. "Computed. Program running." Nikolai bent closer to the display, reading off the anticipated burn and vector, glancing at the bright green line which predicted their new orbit and then to the countdown timer. The first thrust, using Reaction Control jets, which turned Harmonie, was almost imperceptible. Maneuvering rockets then fired to push Harmonie slightly to one side. The collision alert klaxon silenced. Finally, the Reaction Control jets turned Harmonie back on line with her new trajectory. "There, that wasn't so bad, was it?"

"Well, you're such a kiss-ass, Dean, I can only imagine that you pulled for this assignment," Ophelia heard herself saying before she could rein in her mouth. Honesty was the best policy but tact might have been the better course of action. With Ophelia, this was often the case. "Thank you," Midshipman Dean said frostily, his eyes narrowed. "I can't wait until I get aboard and then I'll be able to click glasses together in a toast to my new ship." Click. Yeah, right, Ophelia thought. She further regretted her lack of control and vented it through a slow sigh. Then her temper got the better of her and she leaned over and whispered in his ear, "Yeah, I'm one of the Crazy Lady's Kids. Click! Don't you ever forget it." Dean jerked away as if burnt. "No one ever does, Branford," he told her. "I'll bet that's why they sent you to Sparkle. To be with your sister. All the eggs in one basket." The rest of their time together was spent in silence. Crazy Lady's Kid. Ophelia leaned back and closed her eyes, controlling her breathing and willing herself into a calm reflection. She wondered what it would be like to see her big sister again. Maybe they'd roast marshmallows, Ophelia thought with a snort that caused the irate Dean to jerk in his seat. # Eight years before, fourteen year-old Owami, ‚Äì ever the cool one ‚Äì was roasting marshmallows when the fire trucks pulled up. "Everyone is safe, there's nothing to worry about," she'd told the firemen as they raced to the smoking ruins of a well-appointed house. "My sister had explosives in the oven and ‚Äì" "Explosives in the oven?" the fire captain cried, attracted by the sound of her voice. He rounded on the only other girl there, ten year-old Ophelia. "Dad's on his way," Owami said with a shrug. "And my mother is indisposed." "Indisposed?" "Charlie, don't you know who she is?" the captain said. "You're looking at the kids of the Hero of Canaris." He squinted. "Don't you have a brother?"

Glossary of Terms

Glossary of Terms

AMC: Anti-Matter Container (shorthand ‚Äúamsee‚Äù) - Used to store anti-matter, the fuel source for starships in this universe.

Amsee: Shorthand for Anti-Matter Container (AMC).

Astrogation: Navigation system for starships, including information about warp buoys and other navigational hazards in warp space. Differs from standard navigation, which focuses on location in normal space.

Bots: Robots designed for a variety of tasks, including construction, maintenance, and childcare. The Carlow shipyards used bots extensively, making it possible to construct starships with a relatively small human crew.

ECLSS: Environmental Control and Life Support System (pronounced ‚Äúee-class‚Äù) - Responsible for maintaining a breathable atmosphere and other life support functions within a starship or other enclosed environment.

Fitl: Shorthand term for FTL or Faster-Than-Light travel. Used commonly by spacers, according to Cody.

Ford Clone Line: Cody‚Äôs family line. Clones typically have names starting with the same letter for each generation. The Fords deviate from this tradition, a fact known only to a select few.

Gees: A unit of measurement for acceleration force, often used in the context of spacecraft maneuvering.

Implants: Neural implants, likely located in the temples, that grant the user enhanced cognitive abilities, including faster processing speed and the ability to interface directly with computer systems. The implants also allow for mind-linking under specific circumstances.

Mental Chess: A form of chess played using the implant interface, allowing for direct mind-to-mind competition.

Microgravity: An environment with very weak gravity, such as the environment inside a spacecraft in orbit.

Mind-link: A direct connection between the minds of two or more individuals achieved through compatible neural implants and computer interface. Allows for communication and data transfer at a much faster rate than traditional methods, but can be taxing on the users.

Mothballs: A term used to describe spacecraft or other equipment that has been prepared for long-term storage. Such equipment is typically wrapped and sealed to protect it from the elements and requires some time to be made operational again.

Network: A network of satellites that facilitates communication across the solar system, particularly between the moons of Meath. This network also stores vast amounts of data, allowing users like Ellaz to access historical information.

Chapter One
1747 In The Year Of Our Lord
 In the spring of my fourteenth year, in the fourth year of my training, I was ordered to my Master's study.
My mother was waiting outside the double doors. Her eyes traveled over me critically. She was unsatisfied. She hobbled over to me and slid the leather strap of my necklace under my shirt. Ashamed, I lowered my eyes.
 She hobbled back to her place.
 Master's rules on the strap that held the small leather bag around my neck were strict: in company I was to keep it hidden; in private I was to display it at all times on penalty of whipping -- or worse.
 A bell rang inside the study and my Master's voice boomed out, "Send her in."
 I shot a glance to my mother. I could see that she wanted to accompany me. Instead, she limped back a step or two.
 I raised my head and nodded, as I was taught, to my Master, and walked into the study.
 My mother, emboldened, followed on my tail. "Can I bring anything?"
 Master frowned at her impertinence but waved her away. "I'll ring if I need."
 "Sir," Mother said, lowering her head and retreating, carefully closing the doors with an audible click.
 Inside, I stood waiting. The Captain was seated with his back to me but he craned his neck around for a moment before languidly returning his gaze to the big table to which my Master returned.
 "Step closer," Master ordered, as he sat down, "so the Captain can see you."
 I did as told, calming my breath as taught even though inside I was trembling. Was I to be sold? Would I never see my mother again?
 Why else would I be here? Master Evans loudly proclaimed to any who would listen that he raised "good horses and passable slaves, preferring mares in both." 
It was only recently that he'd decided to branch out.
"I had not thought she'd be so tall," the captain said after a moment, his eyes still traveling over me. I had suffered such looks before; they made my stomach queasy.
"She's well-fed," my Master replied, adding with a chuckle, "comes from good stock."
"Was that her mother?" The Captain said, jerking his head toward the door.
Master Evans nodded.
"Is she ready?" The captain said, turning back to me.
Master Evans looked at me and ordered, "Describe the current state of the empire."
"Massuh," I began, "it is the year of Our Lord 1747, King Charles III reigns on the throne of England." The captain yawned theatrically. "The King reigns over a troubled land in troubled times.
"There are those who say that he arranged for his father, James, to die so that he could accede early to the throne." I could see the captain's eyes narrow. "His brother, Prince Henry, remains a 'guest' of the Pope in Rome -- held in an effort to control the King.
"King Louis XV of France has been trying unsuccessfully to acquire some of the Steam Walkers that were used to bring the crown to Charles. Our King is not so pleased with the French, who treated him niggardly and now seem to feel allowed to impose on his allegiance.
"I predict that will not last," I said, casting my eyes quickly toward the captain to gauge his reaction.
"The rest of Europe is in upheaval, held in abeyance only by the threat of the Steam Walkers," I continued. "King Frederick in Prussia fears that Queen Maria Theresa in Austria will get them before he does and recapture the disputed territory of Silesia from him. He is busy trying to build an alliance with the other German princes, including the survivors of the House of Hanover." I paused for a moment. "His main aim is to form an alliance to attack England, put the Hanoverian princes back on the throne and capture the Steam Walkers and the Royal Steam Artificer, Sir Hamish MacAllister.
"That is the aim of most kings," I continued. "There have been overtures from the King of Spain to buy Steam Walkers, matched readily by those of Piedmont and the Austrians." I paused. "I am given to understand that the Ottoman Empire is considering a war with Austria in the hopes of capturing a Walker of its own or forestalling
